@fuserleer @NorbergSverker @cryptopuff4u Nimbleness around the track is power to weight. Straight line speed is power to wind resistance. So ironically electrics are better for straight line speed given the weight of the batteries. E.g. Model S Plaid has raw power but lighter cars are faster around tight circuits.

@cryptopuff4u @fuserleer All that matters is peak continuous power. IC is so peaky in its torque curve that it needs gears whereas eMotors holds it torque so can run without gears all the way up.

This one doesn't break the argument.

Bisq is a specialised purpose built protocol + Bitcoin technology, not the promise of flexible decentralised apps running smart contract code on L1s which abstracts the need to build your own protocol.

https://t.co/UkIlrBwkXX

This one is deep.

L1s aren't protocols, we'll have many.

Inter-op is impossible in a universe of many L1s.

L1s cannot peer into the state of other L1s. Broken.

https://t.co/UHjrjHjIuQ

I suspect the only value L1s may provide is reliability for the cost of a billion times less efficient than AWS.

It needs Sybil resistance.

I suspect the 2 key issues needed to be solved in order to have true decentralised apps that can fulfill the dream of "Web3" are:

- prevention of sybil attacks
- ability to peer into the global state across all L1s by any dapp. (I think this problem is provably intractable)

Best way to prove me wrong is to name a dapp that provides a benefit that people want that cannot be done by better by existing Web2 and Bitcoin technology.

Example arguments:
- why a DEX will be better than a CEX
- seamless fintech inter-op across the web using MetaMask

DeFi apps can never be truly decentralised.

Anything that works will need trusted centralised parties.

If true, dapps and L1s are just a wild goose chase over an intractable problem.

Please prove me wrong.

SUMMARY:

Overall the BTC is attempting a bottom structure which has not yet confirmed. Locally we are seeing strong spot demand by hodlers, likely institutional.

None of this matters if macro markets crap themselves. If that was off the table, this structure looks pretty good.

Right now we are seeing significant hodler buying (green circle) of the same strength as the Luna Foundation BTC dump (red circle).

It looks to me like some unknown institution(s) are buying significant amounts of spot BTC right now. https://t.co/xidJHABLpD

Taking a fundamental demand and supply view, notice this bear market was driven by futures markets hedging to USD (red arrow), it was not from hodlers selling. Hodlers were accumulating for the most part.

This futures hedging has now subsided. https://t.co/UE0oXfec6p

Normally we see a build up of accumulation (1) near the end of the bear and a large spike at the capitulation event (2).

The large spike is so far missing.

Again, history does not need to repeat as the market is structurally different now in 2022. https://t.co/ifYSJlK3gM

"this time is different"

We are structurally different due to mature futures markets where coins can be hedged out to USD without actually selling or moving coins on-chain.

LN uses invoices and automates the payment process to remove human error; it's well thought out.

Accepting BTC on-chain is like having a teller accepting the cash the buyer fronts at the checkout. Except if they give you the wrong amount they have already left the store.

My support staff dedicated hours every week to handle over and under payments.

Turns out many people pay by withdrawing from their exchange accounts and neglect to account for the exchange withdrawal fee.

I had one guy who accidentally sent me $200k (4 BTC at the time).

The cost of transmitting on the Lightning Network should be the number quoted as a valid comparison. Its energy cost per tx is negligible. Its adoption is in geometric growth.

A BTC L1 payment ($0.55) is full and final settlement, to do that costs $25 and multiple days on SWIFT. https://t.co/u8HH0fIWkT
I'm using $0.05 per kWh which is the average cost of electricity used by the Cambridge Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index.

A single BTC transaction today contains 3.39 batched payments on average. This number continues to become more efficient as exchanges become more efficient in batching their withdrawals together. https://t.co/97b7MFFyLf

Today, the average payment on the BTC L1 network costs 55 cents in fees, the equivalent to 11kWh in electricity. This is 1/1000th of what a US house consumes in a year.

In other words, the NYT article stated a number 200x higher than the truth. https://t.co/nKNqQ63foT

Mechanics:

ETF longs futures.

Futures gets more expensive relative to spot.

Hedge funds sells futures while buying spot (to net the cash and carry profit).

Hedge funds effectively holds spot BTC by proxy for the ETF. The fee being their cash and carry yield (10%+ annualised).

If a Bitcoin futures ETF is approved, IMO it will be an expensive way to hold BTC.

The ETF effectively outsources the holding of BTC to hedge funds through a chain of profit incentives.

@dertomini @PrestonPysh @FossGregfoss It just makes the ETF instrument expensive to hold because the futures bleed is another hedge fund‚Äôs profit via the cash and carry trade.

In effect spot BTC is bought via proxy by hedge funds for an extra fee.

It takes 4 years for complete stabilisation. Though most of the stabilisation happens in the first 3 months.

Thus as time progresses coins in these previously virgin addresses will go from illiquid to whatever the owner's behaviour has been. 

Hence the Illiquid Supply for any given day will slowly drop and stabilise over time as more data comes in.
Later on, that address may interact with other addresses to give clues that the owner is actually an existing owner so the address merges with the old cluster of addresses designated to that owner.
That new owner is classified as "illiquid" because that single address only has a history of buying (that single incoming transaction of coins coming from the exchange).

When coins first move to a virgin address (for example coins bought on an exchange and withdrawn to an HD wallet) there's no historical data on that address, so the heuristics will assume it's a new owner.

The reason why Illiquid Supply is over estimated lies in how Illiquid Supply is derived.

It uses heuristics to cluster wallet addresses together into distinct owners (entities).

As more data comes in, more knowledge comes to light...

Primer... there's 3 classification of owners:

Illiquid - coins owned by "Rick Astley", the people who buy without much selling activity.

Liquid - coins owned by HODLers who buy and sell

Highly Liquid - coins owner by highly speculative people who mainly trade

Deep inside baseball for on-chain analysts...

(1) is sudden and directly impactful than while (2) acts very slowly. Thus it's a bullish.

The over all impact over the long term is neutral as it's all arbitrage which balances out in time. What we are analysing is the short term demand/supply imbalances which may impact price.

2) Spot markets

When GBTC shares unlock and get sold, the GBTC Premium drops (share price drops relative to the BTC in the trust)

Investors now have more incentive to by GBTC shares rather than BTC, it diverts some of the buying pressure on BTC spot markets. This is bearish.

The only catch is you have to hold your shares for 6 months before you can sell them.

The upcoming GBTC unlock we are referring to are these shares unlocking and being available to be sold for cash.

There are 2 impacts on the market:
It's historically been a lucrative trade. At times the premium has traded at over 100% to the underlying BTC in the trust. https://t.co/Nb9fQcEHc2

How does GBTC increase its holdings?

They allow accredited investors to add BTC into the trusts holdings in return for receiving shares in the trust (which normally trades at a premium to BTC).

This is the so-called "carry trade".

Grayscale is a unique product. It's designed as a black hole that sucks in BTC.

No BTC ever leaves the trust, apart from Grayscale taking its 2% management fees from the holdings, this is the only way to reduce the GBTC inventory.

JP Morgan is bearish on the GBTC unlock coming up.

Here I'll go through the inner workings so you can make up your own mind.

There's 2 impacts, one bullish, one bearish. The key is in how they interact. IMO it'll be immediately bullish.

Putting it all together. We run a 2 year moving median of NVT Ratio, that gets us an estimate of the mid-line value also accounting for the drift upwards due to the missing exchange activity. Multiply this by the on-chain volume, and we get a fundamental network valuation. https://t.co/M2WQtiisLC

Notice how NVT is drifting upwards? This is because not all of the investment volume has been accounted for, volume has been moving off the blockchain as exchange dominance increases. https://t.co/C8PPFtf6KW
Oscillations below and above the middle region indicate the market is undervaluing or over valuing the network respectively. https://t.co/3fnaCI39np
NVT oscillates around an imaginary mid-line. That mid-line is in effect the normal ratio that we should multiply volume by to get its valuation. https://t.co/wEQrmTpzc0

I just introduced NVT Ratio.

NVT Ratio is inverse monetary velocity, the co-efficient of proportionality that we can multiple volume by to get market cap. https://t.co/fnTSuGbzbu

Just like we can estimate the valuation of a company by looking at its earnings and multiplying by the expected PE Ratio for its category of company, we can do the same for Bitcoin...  but instead of using PE Ratio and earnings, for Bitcoin we use NVT Ratio and investor volume.

I = M * V

In other words:
M = I * (1/V)

Market cap should fundamentally be proportional to the volume moving between investors.

The co-efficient of proportionality is inverse monetary velocity.

Aha, that's why these 2 lines track each other. https://t.co/2zYUgLLFXp

Let's lay down a first principles equation for a pure store of value network:

value moving between investors = value of the network * how much the money supply churns

In short form:
I = M * V

where:
I = Value moving between investors
M = Market Cap
V = Monetary Velocity

Ever seen this chart of BTC's on-chain volume vs its market cap and wondered why they track so closely?

On-chain volume measures the amount of money moving between investors as seen on the blockchain per day. It's highly correlated to market cap.

But why? https://t.co/CB1yZP5g4I

@thoughtomata M: MarketCap
V: Velocity
I: Value moving between investors (volume)

First Principles: M * V = I

Rewrite: M = I (1/V)
Where 1/V is NVT

Thus marketcap is proportional to volume

NVT changes slowly, so the mismatch is short term deviation or misvaluation by speculators. https://t.co/wDNcqaftj7

In the traditional world it's a 2:1 ratio between derivatives and SoV. That would translate to a BTC dominance of 33%.

The first thing to build is SoV, that's why BTC dominance has been so high. It's possible it continues a downtrend towards 33%.

DeFi in its current form is an experimental area where we figure out how to build networks to buy, sell and transmit risk. For that to happen the underlying networks will need to draw value into their market caps to use as collateral.

SoV buckets (very roughly):
$12T Gold
$90T Fiat
$100T Stocks
$100T Bonds
$250T Real Estate

Derivatives = $1000T+

Derivatives encapsulates the buying, selling and transmission of risk. The modern world is enabled by them.

As large scale commercial industry in orbit starts to develop, it means accessing gold further out is within reach.

Speculative markets always preemptively price things in. It's not a 50 years away thing, the foundations of a large scale space industry is happening today.

$500-$1000 per kg LEO is seen as cost threshold for starting large scale commercial activity in orbit. We are crossing this threshold NOW.

($10 soon.)

The resources out there is enough to support a quadrillion people.

The clock is ticking.

The cost of delta-v is exponentially reducing.

Here's a 2018 chart of projected launch costs (LEO = 9.6 km/s).

We are actually *ahead* of this curve, SpaceX's Starship is expecting a cost of $10 per kg, previously not expected until 2050. It brings us forward 2 decades. https://t.co/GsBps3vBIs

Mining the solar system is limited by the cost of delta-v energy imparted by our rockets.

It takes a lot of energy to hurl mining gear into space.

Remember the moon rocket? Only a tiny part at the top was hurled into space, the rest was burned to get it there.

Delta-v energy requirements (km/s):

9.6 Earth -> LEO (low earth orbit)
6.4 LEO -> Lunar surface
10.7 LEO -> Mars surface

@Tanner35794102 I still use it in conjunction with other metrics. All the metrics change over time as on-chain behaviour and technology evolves. So yes, cross referencing with others is important.

In early and mid phases of a bull market NVT signals very strong investor activity (low NVT) as price continues to climb. You keep buying, as it‚Äôs this activity that is driving up price. It starts to weaken (high NVT) as we approach the top of the bull market.

As more volume continues to trend off chain into layer-2, NVT drifts higher as investment activity becomes invisible to the chain. I tried many methods, the best was simple long term moving averages to track the new zones of buy and sell. It works if the L2 trend is gradual.

‚ÄúInvestor activity‚Äù is predicated on on-chain volume. This is because when BTC moves between wallets between two different participants, we assume there was a payment for it off-chain (fiat or alt-coin). It‚Äôs an imperfect measure but approximates what‚Äôs going on.

NVT Ratio, measures Bitcoin's ratio of investor activity to capitalization. I first described it as Bitcoin's equivalent of a PE Ratio.

Presently NVT is at undervaluation levels equivalent to the COVID19 white swan price bottom. Very bullish. https://t.co/kvE1u7QABV

So all-time impact is $1.70 per dollar invested.

For the impact of the latest dollar, we need to take the current slope of the market cap (change in cap) and divide by the latest slope of the realised cap (change in money invested).

Depending on market phases it changes a lot.

Realised cap approximates the total capital current investors paid for their coins by peering into the blockchain and using the time (and therefore price) at which the coins moved into their wallets.

Eventually even our 4-year cycles will get locked into the gravitational pull of the ~10 year cycles that macro markets exhibit.

BTC will find a new correlation in due time.

You can think of all asset classes as buckets that investors pour their value into, they move allocations from one bucket to the next depending on the season. Assets are correlated because value moves from one to the next.

At a certain point when Bitcoin gets big enough (I'd say above $1T), it will shed its risk-on factor, then its fundamental gold-like properties moves front and center. We get a decoupling from stocks.

So then COVID hits, and everyone is risk off. High net worth players and funds adjust their models and assumptions; they sell off their risk.

BTC dumps and for the first time establishes a high correlation to stocks, and traders currently trade to this self-fulfilling prophecy. https://t.co/mVzmNiXhIx

But mainly BTC's price is just a hockey stick, just like any other high growth / high risk technology on a path to change the world.

So there you have it, a high growth technology investors classify as risk-on, that happens to mimic gold.

A risk-on safe-haven. LOL.
From that point onwards we saw the of an influx of high net worth individuals allocating exposure into BTC. Ever so slightly, correlations to traditional markets started here.

In 2017 that started to change, when @tylerwinklevoss and @winklevoss attempted their launch of a Bitcoin ETF, for the first time Bitcoin was covered in the Wall Street Journal as a legitimate investment asset rather than something dark only the edge of society was into.

BTC was uncorrelated because there was a firewall between traditional macro investors and Bitcoiners. That's to say cypherpunks, tech-heads, purveyors and consumers of illicit drugs, and die hard libertarians are NOT typically the guys moving money in macro markets.

A couple of years ago Bitcoin was marketed as the new uncorrelated asset, thus fund managers really needed to have it as part of their portfolio else they would not have a portfolio that would be hedged for all situations.

This is an on-point Q right now. Short answer is yes on-chain is relevant as whatever investors are doing, whether it dumps or pumps, for reason A, B or C, then it shows up on-chain.

As the sell pressure reduction from each halvening cycle reduces, the impulse has less strength. Eventually the scale of halvenings become insignificant, Bitcoin's 4 year cycle will start to transition into the resonance of traditional markets (~10 years).

How far that bullish impulse runs for is determined by specifics in each macro cycle, so you can't measure it from peak to peak, it's impulse to impulse. Some pundits say we are lengthening in cycles by measuring peak to peak, this is curve fitting devoid of fundamentals.

The Bitcoin 4 year bull/bear cycle is caused by sell pressure reduction every 4 years by the BTC halvening. That impulse creates a resonance, like a slosh of water in a bath tub when you push it timed just right. The magic happens at the impulse. https://t.co/wvYixTPV9w

That 40 BTC tx added ~3% to the aggregate destruction value for all transactions on 20 May 2020. 

To give you an idea of variability of destruction day to day, here's some raw values (green text) from the last week.

40BTC * 10yrs is insignificant. Not discernible from noise. https://t.co/l2RoBdu9QR

The technical term the Bitcoin community created for this effect is called "Destruction". 

Destruction = Coins moved * Total time those coins were dormant

AKA Bitcoin Days Destroyed. This was one of the first on-chain metrics invented.

Old coins moving increases both realised cap (orange) and the CVDD price floor model (pink) for valuation.

When old investors sell out of their sub $1 coins, it allows for the price floor to increase. New buyers capitulate at much higher prices. (Long term bullish) https://t.co/4XEY9omiEI

Since coins moving is ultimately a movement of capital between investors, you want to know who's the "smarter money". Most likely the investor with the longest time in the market is the smarter one, they sell near local macro tops. (Locally bearish)

Is 40 BTC worth of coins moving from 2009 ...

Bearish? YES

Bullish? Also YES

Significant? NO**

**Assuming they are not Satoshi's coins.

When I look at the long term price chart of BTCUSD 2017-2020, the rise of the BitMEX style futures exchanges has made a irrevocable footprint on the price, we have much more sideways now from the additional sell pressure.

To hit this home, it's really quite easy to generate $400m of monthly futures trading volume from a $500k collateral account when trading short term candles. That generates as much as $80k of fees for the exchange. 8BTC of fees sold onto the market that month on a 50BTC account.

With the rise of BitMEX and now strong competing futures exchanges all pushing billion dollar daily trade volumes, the picture looks like this:

1800 BTC/day from miners pre-halvening
900 BTC/day from miners post-halvening
1200 BTC/day from exchange fees

There‚Äôs only two unmatched sell pressures on the market. (1) Miners who dilute the supply and sell onto the market, this is the hidden tax via monetary inflation. And (2) the exchanges who tax the traders and sell onto the market.

This is very different from traders buying or selling. When we say traders are ‚Äúbuying‚Äù or ‚Äúselling‚Äù this is a myth. Every trade is matched, every trade has a buyer and a seller. (When we say the market is buying or selling, we actually mean smart money is buying or selling.)

You can think of exchanges as tax agents on traders. That tax, extracted in fees in BTC, gets dumped onto the markets and sold for fiat. It‚Äôs similar to miners where coins gained by diluting the supply get dumped on the market that new demand needs to absorb.

Post this 2020 halvening miners will cease to be the biggest sellers of Bitcoin. It'll be the dawn of the crypto exchange as the leading seller.

The biggest sell pressure on Bitcoin will soon be from exchanges selling their BTC fees collected into fiat.

@TuurDemeester I look at it like that too, but key differences make it nuanced beyond standard leverage trades. Includes tax treatment and government support in differing countries. You don‚Äôt get liquidated if you‚Äôre underwater, only if you stop funding payments. Houses aren‚Äôt fungible.

Well this time around, we have gone $14k->$7.5k and that's killing off weak miners who are dumping and dying. This adds to the already bearish action, so no happy front running 6-momnths out due to sell pressure. You can't draw repeat fractals, the fundamentals are different.
Historically everyone draws these nice picture perfect front-running pumps 6-months before the halvening. They fail to notice that was under bullish price action.

I'll elaborate. As price moves downwards, weak miners go out of business. This happened when we went $6k->$3k, the bottom happened when weak miners were dead and no longer dumping onto the market. The market bottoms afterwards.

NEVER gone into a halvening in BEARISH price action, miners already capitulating adding sell volume. Historically we front run with a BULLISH setup, miner capitulating only after halvening when revenues are slashed. This is a unique setup. We can take this understanding back to Bitcoin investors. The only "app" that cannot easily be transported to a new network is SoV as it has network effect lock in.

Bear that in mind next time a big blocker pitches more utility on its network like BCH or BSV.

Your token will NOT monetise from blockchain apps in the long term, the best it can do is be a cheap play pen for prototyping, if an app goes big (that's another big IF), the app will always move off your network and onto its own natively built one.

In the blockchain world that would look like a fork, then a home grown blockchain custom designed for their own needs.

With the Polychain thesis, you would be betting FB would build Libra on Ethereum or similar. LOL. 

--> A company at scale will ALWAYS roll its own stack.

E.g. Facebook started on PHP, it was known to Zucks and fast for him to build on. Then they created their own compiled PHP for speed. Today they use many languages including ones of their own design such as GraphQL solving the need for backward compatibility between app<->server.

These networks do not behave like simple protocols like TCP/IP, SMTP, HTTP, etc. They are complex merger of protocol and scripting language. 

We already know how this plays out. A product using one language will switch parts or all of its app to newer languages as needs change.

I.e. "disproportionate returns go to holders of the tokens rather than investors in private companies built on top of the protocols."

Apart from ICO fundraising, which is an illegal security sale, this idea is not sustainable.

This is where the popular investment thesis which powered a lot of shitcoin investing in 2017 (originating from Polychain Capital) IMO is completely broken. The idea being tokens are ways for opensource protocols to monetise as apps are built on it.

@bradmillscan @PolymathNetwork @radixdlt He should build it on middleware that allows transport other and newer networks or sidechains. Take a lead from Tether, you want to move networks as better tech comes to suit your needs.
@100trillionUSD @awertheim Will do. Thanks.

As for protecting yourself, be sure to 2FA your email, and remove any mobile phone 2FA. Also 2FA all your other exchange accounts. Breach of your email is an identity leak, whereby the attacker may attempt to hack your email and use it to compromise your other exchange accounts.
So there is a chance if your email was off the tail end of the truncation, your email did not get breached.

My best guess is that leak originated from a developer bug in BitMEX's software sending out mass emails. The email header is malformed, the software crammed loads of email addresses into the To: header field to the point the last email in the list was truncated.

This can be done by intercepting the email logs at the intermediary SMTP servers that the email hopped between, email headers are sent in unencrypted clear text between mail servers. Maybe someone here knows how easy that would be.

Since there is a limit to how many characters that can be injected into the To: field, the email software would have chunked the email into tens of thousands of batches, all batches would have to be collated to collect the entire database.
Just looking into this privacy breach by BitMEX. Customers were emailed with other customer's email addresses visible in the To: field.

If you're about to sign up to BitMEX under a new email after they leaked your old one. You may as well give FTX a go, here's my ref-link. All proceeds will go to my fund, I call it the beer fund, thanks. :)

As a final note, notice how the 2019 the 2012 bull market have the same structure, we saw severe mining capitulation (ribbon flipped negative) leading to a shorter accumulation band before price breakout. This bull market has resembles 2012 more than 2016 structurally. https://t.co/qcRaZVdHTg

Miners capitulate in bears, but also during block reward halvening events when suddenly only half the coins are mined for the same costs and the market price has yet to catch up to pay for it. See the compression after each halvening (marked as vertical lines) as miners die off. https://t.co/IwRdpJ4DFt

Credit goes to @VinnyLingham who was the first AFAIK to spot this dynamic in his April 2014 article on how Bitcoin finds its price equilibrium. We now have 5 more years of data to back it up.
https://t.co/W80Ikz72y4

Typically we see this at the end of bear cycles, after miners capitulate, the lack of miner selling pressure allows the price to stabilise and then climb; the classic accumulation bottom. https://t.co/yiiBRlxagA

The weakest miners sell more of their coins to remain operational. When it becomes unsustainable, they capitulate, hashing power and network difficulty reduces (ribbon compression), leaving only the strong, who sell less leaving more room for more bullish price action.

This indicator speaks to the impact of mining on Bitcoin's price. As new coins are mined into existence, miners sell some of their mined coins to pay for production costs. This produces bearish price pressure.

Introducing the Bitcoin Difficulty Ribbon. When the ribbon compresses, or flips negative, these are the best time to buy in and get exposure to Bitcoin. The ribbon consists of simple moving averages on mining difficulty so we can easily see the rate of change in difficulty. https://t.co/6kBz4sLG1d

@mrauchs @nic__carter @coinmetrics @onchainfx Another way to say this. (1) measures the GDP of the external (world/country/city) economy under BTC as the yardstick while (2) measures Bitcoin‚Äôs GDP with USD as the yardstick.

@mrauchs @nic__carter @coinmetrics @onchainfx That mixes two concepts:

(1) Settlement for goods and services for an external economy (BTC is not about payments)

(2) How much service BTC delivers

Commentary by @hansthered on the TAAR indicator published in @coindesk. TLDR; small ticket retail have been buying into this rally, the whales are biding their time still, we await the volume generated by their big ticket buys to drive us into a sustainable bull market.
Altcoins can act as a SoV in weekly to monthly time frames, but only during bull markets. However the many have not proven they are capable of storing value over a complete bull-bear cycle.

Fiat is a good SoV for HODL on monthly timeframes.

Gold and houses can act as a SoV for HODLs over many years, ideally decades or more.

Bitcoin is good SoV for HODL periods of 4 years+

Example: That 0.05ETH users buy to pay for some ERC20s transactions gives ETH a valuation of a few bucks. That 50ETH investors buy to HODL gives it a valuation of hundreds of dollars. ETH is primarily valued as a SoV, not at all for its utility as a world computer.

In fact the majority of value accrual for all blockchains and coins is from SoV. That‚Äôs because utility valuations work out low (MV=PQ) and nobody is really using these chains yet at any kind of scale.

Bitcoin‚Äôs core utility is that of a store of value. Speculation is the foundation of SoV. If you buy into an asset, you need someone to buy it off you later, hopefully at the same or higher price. You‚Äôve stored value for a period.

4) A tidal wave of buys cascade through the orderbooks, a chain reaction, the price goes vertical.

5) Whale payday. The whales that bought up the market sheparding the price up now dump their positions at profit.  

6) Blow-off. The price comes down to its organic levels.

The mechanics of short squeezes 101:

1) When the market is majority short, there's too much money to be had to allow them to win.

2) Whales keep buying up the market until the shorts get liquidated.

3) At liquidation the short seller has to buy back at market price.

Balanced Price by @kenoshaking added. It's an experimental attempt at capturing Bitcoin's fair valuation by measuring the difference between what was paid (Realised Price) and what was spent (Transferred Price). It tends to highlight the accumulation zones. https://t.co/fl0MC6IUPB

CVDD and Top Price models helps us frame the room in which BTC price account may wander between. https://t.co/lVele0lpg6
When used in conjunction with @coinmetrics' Realised Price, CVDD is useful in visualising accumulation bottoms. https://t.co/HnQjp0Qc65

There is a calibration factor (6 million) involved, but once calibrated, CVDD catches all prior bottoms. It has the useful property of tending to increase over time, so useful in bear cycles when we want to gauge an estimate of the (rising) bottom zone. https://t.co/Ncslx2FlV4

When a HODLer sells to another HODLer the transaction contains both value (USD) and a length of prior HODL time. CVDD is the cumulative sum of this value and time destruction for every on-chain transaction (adjusted by age of market which brings the units back into USD).

@BitcoinTina NVT works off the investment velocity of the network. 

M * V = I

M = 1/V * I

M = NVT * I

(I = investment flow, M = market cap, V = velocity)

High NVT means more of the network is in long term HODL. Low NVT means there‚Äôs lots less HODL.

(1) (2) and (4) are usually objective. 

(3) is often faked, look deeply into (3) and make sure the network effects are true and here to stay.

An investor should be careful regarding organic liquidity and inorganic. The former is a sign that real people are using the asset as a SoV and this means you can exit when bucket reallocation time comes. If it's inorganic, the market maker may quit and you're left high and dry.

Many projects are trying to bootstrap (3) by employing market makers to stimulate liquidity. Also marketing the impression of a growing ecosystem with MOUs of partnerships, this is all hot air. Look for organic growth, it's the hard yards that matter.

(1) (2) and (4) are often discussed. (3) is not emphasised enough. The network effects are key. No other crypto-asset has the liquidity / Lindy Effect / infrastructure close to Bitcoin. Ethereum is a clear second, but fails on (2).

What gives a network good properties for SoV? I like @MustStopMurad's prioritised framework of:
(1) Security
(2) Credibility of fixed monetary policy
(3) Liquidity / Lindy Effect / Infrastructure / Ecosystem
(4) Governance / Adaptability / Community / Game Theoretic Robustness

Utility is a reason to attract usage, marketing exposure in a way (in the eyes of an investor), but without SoV properties in the network, the network won't sustain high long term capital appreciation apart from short term noob fuelled bubbles. Or what we saw with ETH.

Unfortunately for ETH, the ERC20 contract that opened the pathway for ETH as a SoV was inorganic. It forced ETH as a currency to raise funds. It seemed good to keep funds in ETH as ICO mania pushed values up. Easy up = easy down. Treasuries bailed ETH cascading it down.

To hit this home in crypto... the ETH rise in value was NOT from utility. It wasn't from users buying ETH to get Gas to fuel smart contracts. It was ICO token treasuries parking their funds in ETH as a store of value.

Make no mistake that the majority of asset value in the world is derived from players parking value into an asset for storage. Whether that be a house, a lump of gold, or even, to a lesser extent, stocks.

Store of value properties is what gives crypto networks value, utility is overrated for the purposes of investment appreciation - utility is a red herring for investors.

In the case of Bitcoin, its real utility is really just a bucket, it's a bucket to store value.

@cburniske Digital gold is a metaphor for a good store of value. DCR has security on its side. OTOH BTC has natural liquidity & Lindy Effect, both of these are immensely important for a "digital gold" and can only be achieved by long term organic growth.
